{{Too many sections|date=January 2018}} The '''Chitrapur Guru Parampara''' ([[Devanagari script|Devanagari]] चित्रापुर गुरु परंपरा,''{{IAST|Gu.ru Pa.ram.pa.ra}}'') or ''Guru Heritage'' of the [[Chitrapur Saraswat Brahmins|Chitrāpur Sāraswat Brahmins]] is the lineage of spiritual teachers ([[guru]]s), also known as ''Mathadhipatis ({{IAST|Ma.thā.dhi.pa.ti}})'' (head of the [[Chitrapur Math|Chitrāpur Math]], ''{{IAST|Chi.trā.pur Ma.th}}'') who have led the community throughout its history. These teachers are viewed as the torch-bearers of the rich culture and heritage that the community has passed down from generation to generation. Starting with [[Parijnanashram I|Param Poojya Parijnanāshram I Swamiji]] in 1708, the [[Parampara]] (lineage) continues through to the present ''Mathādhipati'' of the Chitrāpur Math [[Sadyojat Shankarashram|Param Poojya Sadyojāt Shankarāshram Swamiji]]. He is currently the 11th ''Mathādhipati'' of the Shri Chitrapur Math. ==The Parampara== This chart shows the lineage of Paramparas. It shows the reigning period of each ''Mathādhipati'' along with his place of birth as well as place where his shrine (''samādhi'') is located.{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=Guru Parampara|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Mathādhipati ! Reign ! Birthplace ! Samādhi |- | [[Parijnanashram I|Param Poojya Parijñānāshram Swamiji I]] | (1708–1720) | Unknown | [[Gokarn]] |- | [[Shankarashram I|Param Poojya Shankarāshram Swamiji I]] | (1720–1757) | Haritē | [[Shirali]] |- | [[Parijnanashram II|Param Poojya Parijñānāshram Swamiji II]] | (1757–1770) | [[Kollur, Udupi district|Kollur]] | Shirali |- | [[Shankarashram II|Param Poojya Shankarāshram Swamiji II]] | (1770–1785) | Mallāpur | Mallāpur |- | [[Keshavashram|Param Poojya Keshavāshram Swamiji]] | (1785–1823) | Kandlūr | Shirali |- | [[Vamanashram|Param Poojya Vāmanāshram Swamiji]] | (1823–1839) | [[Mangalore]] | Mangalore |- | [[Krishnashram|Param Poojya Krishnāshram Swamiji]] | (1839–1863) | Vithal | Shirali |- | [[Pandurangashram|Param Poojya Pandurangāshram Swamiji]] | (1863–1915) | Mangalore | Shirali |- | [[Anandashram Swami|Param Poojya Anandāshram Swamiji]] | (1915–1966) | Shirali | Shirali |- | [[Parijnanashram III|Param Poojya Parijñānāshram Swamiji III]] | (1966–1991) | [[Mumbai]] | [[Karli, India|Karla]] |- | [[Sadyojat Shankarashram|Param Poojya Sadyojāt Shankarāshram Swamiji]] | (1997–Present) | [[Chennai]] | |} ==The Saraswat Brahmins== {{Main|Chitrapur Saraswat Brahmins}} ''Saraswat ({{IAST|Sā.ra.swat}})'' is the generic term for the [[Brahmins]] or learned people who inhabited the fertile basin between the ancient rivers of Saraswati and Drishadawati in [[Kashmir]].{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace |last=Divgi |first=Jyothi|pages=23|year=2002}} But usually Saraswat refers to the Saraswat Brahmins who come under the ''[[Chitrapur Math|Chitrāpur Matha]]'' at [[Shirali|Shirāli]] and are hence called Chitrāpur Sāraswat Brahmins (Bhānaps or Smārtha Sāraswats). Due to drought and famine, they migrated southwards towards Goa and Maharashtra. But Portuguese invasion of Goa forced the Sāraswats established neat Gomantak region to migrate further south towards Karnataka and settled down in the [[Kanara]] regions of [[Karnataka]].{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=27|year=2002}} Their superior intelligence and administrative experience helped them attain several important posts in the regions in which they migrated to.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=29|year=2002}} The Bhanap people are a very small community that is scattered in all parts of the globe. The common thread that binds all these people is the ''Guru Parampara'' and the ''Chitrapur Math'' ==The origin of the Guruparampara== During the reign of the Hindu chiefs of Nagar or Keldi (1560–1768){{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=Shrimat Parijananashram Swamiji -I (Gokarn)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} in the Kanara regions of Karnataka, the Smartha Saraswats held esteemed positions in the government. These were a variety of administrative and accountancy positions. Since they were established in villages of the region, they adopted the names of the villages as their surnames. Their superior intelligence and high efficiency of work{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=28|year=2002}} created envy among the local people there. Their jealousy went to such an extent that they wanted to remove the Saraswats from their highly respective posts. For this they went and complained to the King of Nagar that the Saraswats did not have a [[Guru]] and hence did not have a spiritual existence of their own. The King heeded the words of these envious people and issued an official decree whereby "If the Saraswats did not show him their ''Guru'', a heavy penalty would be imposed upon them". It so happened that the Guru of the [[Chitrapur Saraswat Brahmin#Shenvis|Shenvis]] had left for [[Benaras]]. The representative of the Saraswat community made this point to the King but he was not satisfied with it. The Saraswat Brahmins were aghast. All the elders of the community held a ''dharan'' (community prayer) at the Temple of Lord Mahābaleshwar (''Bhavānishankar'') at [[Gokarna, India#Religious attractions|Gokarna]]. The intensity of prayer is as quoted:
''The Saraswats gathered together,
And prayed in all humility,
Giving up hunger,thirst and sleep...''
''Such was the intensity'' ''The devotees with prayers in their hearts,
Unceasingly for long nights and days,
Surrendered unto Lord Mahabaleshwar,
At Gokarn,that sacred place.''{{cite book| last =Divgi| first =Jyothi| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Anugraha-A saga of cascading grace| publisher =Shri Chitrapur Math| date =September 2002| location =| pages =31| url =http://www.chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM| doi =| id =| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071017152230/http://chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM| archivedate =2007-10-17| df =}}
Lord Bhavānishankar is said to have answered their prayers. In a dream he appears and assures his devotees that a [[Sanyasi]] would arrive at the banks of the ''Kotiteerth''the next day and that he would guide the community as their Guru. As the dream had proclaimed, a ''sanyasi'' clad in saffron robes and carrying the ''vigraha'' (idol) of Lord Bhavānishankara in his cloth pouch arrived at the banks of the ''Kotiteerth ({{IAST|Ko.ti.tī.rth}})'', the village tank.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=35|year=2002}}
"Sacred ash smeared on the forehead,
The Guru arrived,the Benevolent One,
Clad in flaming saffron robes,
Resplendent like the Sun! A 'Danda' adorned in one hand,
A 'Kamandalu' in another,
The brilliance of Shankara on his face,
The gentle smile of a mother! A 'rudraksha mala' adorned his nech,
A 'Jholi' by His side,
Carried the 'Vigraha' of Lord Bhavanishankara,
Our Gurudev had come down to guide."{{cite book| last =Divgi| first =Jyothi| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Anugraha-A saga of cascading grace| publisher =Shri Chitrapur Math| date =September 2002| location =| pages =35| url =http://www.chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM| doi =| id =| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071017152230/http://chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM| archivedate =2007-10-17| df =}}
This great one was [[Parijnanashram I|Parijñānāshram I]], the first Guru, who established in 1708, the glorious ''Guru parampara'' in which the present [[guru]] [[Sadyojat Shankarashram|Sadyojāt Shankarāshram]] is the eleventh in succession ==Sāraswats under the Swamis== The Sāraswats have lived a glorious period of over 300 years under the ''Guru Parampara''. Each swamiji has contributed in his own way to the development of the community. The divine powers possessed by the greats and their deeds towards humanity are stuff of legends. ===Under Parijñānāshram I (1708–1720)=== {{main|Parijnanashram I|l1=Swami Parijñānāshram I}} The Saraswat installed Swami Parijñānāshram I at the ''Sri Vishveshwar Vithal'' Temple and brought him to Nāgar and before the king. But the king refused to accept him as their [[guru]] until and unless the ''[[Shankaracharya|Shankarāchārya]]'' of the [[Sringeri Sharada Peetham]] gave his consent. ''Parijñānāshram Swamiji'' travelled from Gokarna to Shringeri. At first he was denied entry into the temple by the priests there. In the night "Jagadguru" had a dream where he saw that idol of Sharada Devi had lost its lustre as she was upset as her son was denied entry into the temple. In the morning the ''Jagadguru'' realised this when he saw the idol and immediately called for Parijnanashram Swamiji and gave his consent to the new Swamiji. He was also awestruck by Parinanashram swamiji's piety, yogic abilities and his knowledge.{{cite book |title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=39–40|year=2002}} The King wholeheartedly welcome the new ''Mathādhipati'' of the Sāraswats. Thus the Guru parampara was established. The Swamiji consented to stay on at the ''Sri Vishweshwar Vithal'' Temple on the banks of the Kotiteerth in [[Gokarna, India|Gokarna]] which became the first ''Math'' or monastery (The [[Parijnanashram I#Adi-matha|''Adi Matha'']]) of the Sāraswats. He led the community till 1720 when [[Shankarashram I|Shankārashram I Swami]] became the ''Mathādhipati'' (head of the ''matha'': generic name for head of the community). He attained ''Mahāsamādhi''(death) on the ''Krishna Chaturdashi'' day of the month of ''[[Chaitra]]'' in 1720.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace |last=Divgi |first=Jyothi|pages=47|year=2002}} His ''samādhi'' is located at [[Shirali|the Adi Matha, Gokarna]] ===Under Shankarāshram I (1720–1757)=== {{Main|Shankarashram I|l1=Swami Shankarāshram I}} Swami Shankarāshram was the ''mathādhipati'' from 1720 until his ''Mahāsamadhi'' in 1757. Under his leadership, the [[Chitrapur Math|Chitrāpur Math]] at [[Shirali|Shirāli]] became the head ''math'' (monastery) of the Sāraswats. His divinity has many popular folklore attached to it. Many devotees in grief and sorrow attained happiness due to his divine grace (see [[Shankarashram I#Miracles|Swamiji's Miracles]]). Swamiji suddenly suffered from an untimely illness and succumbed to it and attained ''Mahāsamādhi'' in 1757.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=57|year=2002}} His ''samādhi'' is located at [[Shirali]]. He had not adopted a ''shishya'' (disciple) to continue the lineage or ''parampara''. ===Under Parijnānāshram II (1757–1770)=== {{Main|Parijnanashram II|l1=Swami Parijñānāshram II}} With ''Shankarāshram I Swamiji'' attaining ''samādhi'' without ordaining a new successor, the community was again put into a state of peril. The King had again seized the assets of the math with the condition that a new ''mathadhipati'' had to be installed.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=59–60|year=2002}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |title=H. H. Shrimat Parijananashram Swamiji -II (Shirali)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} The elders of the community gathered together and sought to resolve the impending peril. They went to a saintly person, who practised [[yoga]], from the ''Pandit'' family in [[Kollur, Udupi district|Kollur]] and asked him if he would take up the reins of the ''Mathādhipati''. He graciously accepted and thus was ordained as Parijñānāshram II Swamiji.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=61|year=2002}} Not being the type who liked to wield power, Swamiji accepted a ''shisya'' (disciple) very soon and spent most of his time practising yoga at Kollur. He attained ''Mahāsamādhi'' in 1770 leaving behind his successor ''Shankarāshram II''. His ''samādhi'' is located at [[Shirali]] ===Under Shankarāshram II (1770–1785)=== {{Main|Shankarashram II|l1=Shankarāshram II Swamiji}} Swami Shakarāshram II was considered as the ''avatār''(incarnation) of ''[[Dattareya|Lord Dattātreya]]''.{{cite web | last = Math | first = Chitrapur | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = H. H. Shrimat Shankarashram Swamiji -II (Mallapur) | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}}{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=77|year=2002}} He was a true ''Jñāni'' (knowledgeable one) and people from all parts of the country flocked to hear his spiritual discourses. Very many miracles have been attributed to him (''see [[Shankarashram II#Mircales|Miracles]]''). In 1781, swamiji accepted a ''shishya'' (disciple) and christened him ''Keshavāshram''.{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |title=H. H. Shrimat Shankarashram Swamiji -II Mallapur)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} In 1785 swamiji attained ''Mahāsamādhi'' and ''Swami Keshavāshram'' became the fifth ''mathādhipati'' of the Sāraswat Brahmins. The ''samādhi'' of His Holiness Shankarāshram Swamiji is located at the small hamlet of Mallāpur in Karnataka at the Mallāpur Math. ===Under Keshavāshram (1785–1823)=== {{Main|Keshavashram|l1=Keshavāshram Swamiji}} Keshavāshram Swamiji took charge of the math in 1785. He was a very learned person and a scholar in the Sanskrit scriptures. Knowing that education was the key to success, Keshavāshram Swamiji encouraged the Sāraswats to have English education during British rule.{{cite book|title=Guruparampara Charita Saramrita(Devanagari)|publisher=Shri Chitrapur Math Publication|pages=25–27|year=2002}} Thus when the other communities ostracized the English language, the Saraswats got well-educated in English and thus could hold positions of high esteem even under the British. He is attributed with very many miracles (see [[Keshavashram#Miracles|Miracles]]) and the popularity of the ''matha'' got a tremendous boost under his ''Ādhipatya'' (governance). He accepted a ''shishya'' in 1804 and ordained him '''Vāmanāshram'''.{{cite book |title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=85|year=2002}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=H. H. Shrimat Keshavashram Swami(Shirali)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} Thus another sacred link was added to the ''Guru parampara''. In the year 1823, Keshavāshram Swamiji attained ''Mahā-samadhi''. His ''samādhi'' is located at [[Shirali]]{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace |last=Divgi |first=Jyothi |pages=87|year=2002}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=H. H. Shrimat Keshavashram Swami (Shirali)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} ===Under Vāmanāshram (1823–1839)=== {{Main|Vamanashram|l1=Vāmanāshram Swamiji}} Vāmansāshram Swamiji became the ''mathadhipati'' in 1823. Vāmanāshram Swamiji had the distinction of serving as the ''shishya'' of Keshavāshram Swamiji for 19 years. He was a person who was more involved in spiritual pursuits than in administration. To reduce the burdens of administration, he accepted a ''shishya''.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=91|year=2002}} This shishya was ordained as ''Krishnāshram'' in the year 1836.{{cite web |url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |title=H. H. Shrimat Vamanashram Swami (Mangalore)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} After accepting a ''shishya'' Vamanāshram Swamiji gave up the administrative responsibilities and took the path of ''[[Tyāga]]'' (sacrifice) in 1836. Stories of his divine powers and intensity of prayer are legends among the Sāraswats (see [[Vamanashram#Miracles|Miracles]]). Swamiji attained ''Mahā-samādhi'' in 1839. His ''samādhi'' stands at [[Mangalore]] within the premises of the Mangalore Math. ===Under Krishnāshram (1839–1863)=== {{Main|Krishnashram|l1=Krishnāshram Swamiji}} Param Poojya Krishnāshram Swamiji gained control over the ''matha'' in 1839. He was a dynamic and able administrator.{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=H. H. Shrimat Krishnashram Swami (Shirali)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} His contributions to architecture and infrastructure still stand today. He ordered the construction of temples and ''mathas'', set right existing ones and gradually got over many people from their [[Vaishnava]] practises. Swamiji accepted a ''shishya'' in 1857 and ordained him as ''Pāndurangāshram''.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace |last=Divgi |first=Jyothi|pages=104|year=2002}} With the dynamism of youth in Pādurangāshram swami, Swami Krishnāshram could introduce many reforms for the benefit of the community. Swami Krishnāshram attained ''Maha-samadhi'' in 1863. His ''samadhi''(shrine) is located at Shirali.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=117|year=2002}} ===Under Pāndurangāshram (1863–1915)=== {{Main|Pandurangashram|l1=Pāndurangāshram Swamiji}} Param Poojya Pāndurangāshram took charge of the ''math'' in 1863. He is the longest serving ''Mathādhipati'' till date (52 years). He is considered one of the most brilliant of all the swamis and his mastery over [[Sanskrit]] and [[Logic]] was unquestionable.{{cite book |title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=118–119|year=2002}} Even after taking charge of the ''matha'', he continued to learn the [[Vedanta]] and the [[Upanishads]]. He stressed on the need for education in the community. Under his guidance, a school was established and he brought about the development of general infrastructure of Shirāli.{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=H. H. Shrimat Pandurangashram Swami (Shirali)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} Swamiji stressed [[Dharma]] (the right way to live) and encouraged a sense of patriotism in his country.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace |last=Divgi |first=Jyothi |pages=121 |year=2002}} He came under criticism for imposing a ban on foreign travel. Anyone who went abroad or anyone who associated with a person who went abroad were excommunicated. Overall, the period under the leadership of Swami ''Pāndurangāshram'' is called the "Glorious Age" of the Saraswats.{{cite book| last =Math| first =Chitrapur| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Guruparampara Charita Saramrita| publisher =Chitrapur Math Publications| date =| location =| pages =| url =http://www.chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM| doi =| id =| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071017152230/http://chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM| archivedate =2007-10-17| df =}} Miracles have been attributed to swamiji. Swamiji was reluctant in adopting a ''shishya'' because of the lack of discipline within the community. Eventually when swamiji was very sick, he relented to the pressure of the people and accepted a ''shishya''. The new ''shishya'', who was just 8 years old, was ordained as ''Ānandāshram''.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=135–137|year=2002}} Thus a sacred link in the ''Guru Parampara'' could be established. Pāndurangāshram Swamiji attained ''Mahā-samādhi'' in 1915. His ''samādhi'' is at Shirāli.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=141|year=2002}} ===Under Ānandāshram (1915–1966)=== {{Main|Anandashram Swami|l1=Ānandāshram Swamiji}} Ānandāshram Swamiji had served as ''mathādhipati'' for a glorious period of 51 years. Those were the years when India went through turbulent times of the [[Indian Independence Struggle|Independence struggle]]. Under Ānandāshram Swamiji the Sāraswat community developed at a rapid rate. The financial development was given top priority as the community was facing a financial crisis{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |title=H. H. Shrimat Anandashram Swami (Shirali)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} during the early parts of his reign. He brought about many social reforms like permission to go abroad and taking back the people from the community who had been ostracized for foreign visits.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=165|year=2002}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=H. H. Shrimat Anandashram Swami (Shirali)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} The community underwent tremendous progress economically and morally under his regime. Swami Anandashram accepted a ''shishya'' in 1959 and ordained him as Parijñānāshram. Swamiji attained ''Mahā-samādhi'' in 1966. His ''samadhi'' is in Shirali.{{cite book |title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=167–174|year=2002}} ===Under Parijñānāshram III(1966 - 1991)=== {{Main|Parijnanashram III|l1=Parijñānāshram III Swamiji}} Parijñānāshram Swamiji took charge of the ''matha'' after the glorious years under Swami Ānandāshram. He was very intelligent, had a progressive outlook and a keen thirst for knowledge — Vedic as well as technical. His dynamic approach to matters regarding the ''matha'' brought back the financial stability it needed. His scientific temper resulted in the establishment of a printing press, Observatory and other technical advancements.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=179–183|year=2002}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=H. H. Shrimat Parijnanashram Swamiji-III (Karla)|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} He was responsible for the starting of cottage and small-scale industries like printing press, handlooms and powerlooms, agro-industries in the regions around the ''math''. With the financial stability regained, the ''[[Chitrapur Math#Rathotsav|Rathōtsav]]'' (Car Festival) was restarted; it had been stopped under Swami Ānandāshram due to acute financial strain.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=179–183}} His far-sighted and monumental development ideas did not go well with the "orthodox" members of the community. This resulted in a rift in the community. It also led to an open display of disrespect toward this Swamiji by certain lobbies. ''Swamiji'' true to his divine grace made the ultimate ''Tyāga'' (sacrifice) by giving up the administration of the ''matha'' in 1981. This was reminiscent of Swami Vāmanāshram who had done the same in 1836.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace|last=Divgi|first=Jyothi|pages=184–186}} Swami Parijñānāshram III attained ''Mahā-samādhi'' in 1991. His ''samādhi'' is at [[Karli, India|Karla]] in Maharashtra.{{cite book|title=Anugraha-A Saga of cascading grace |last=Divgi |first=Jyothi |pages=189}} After the Samadhi of Parampoojya Parijnanashram Swamiji, the Karla Math continues to be managed by the Chitrapur Saraswat Brahmin community, under guidance from His successor, H H Sadyojat Shankarashram Swamiji, the 11th Guru in the Chitrapur Saraswat Guruparampara and spiritual head of the institutions running the Karla Math. ===Under Sadyojāt Shankarāshram (1997–present)=== {{Main|Sadyojat Shankarashram|l1=Sadyojāt Shankarāshram Swamiji}} After a 6-year search for a Guru, (1991–1997) the Sāraswat community was blessed with a Mathādhipati and Guru - H H Param Poojya Sadyojāt Shankarāshram Swamiji. In Him the community found an erudite Vedic Scholar, an exponent of the advaitic Philosophy of Adi Shankaracharya,Teacher, reformist leader. and much more. Ordained into Sanyas by HH Swami Ishwarānanda Giriji Maharaj as Sadyojāt Samvat Giri[59][60]., He took up the reins of Shri Chitrapur Math in February 1997 as Sadyojat Shankarashram Swami at a well attended, elaborate Ceremony graced and blessed by H H Shankaracharya of Shringeri Shardamba Peetham.{{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title=H. H. Shrimat Sadyojat Shankarashram Swamiji|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} Under Swami Sadyojāt Shankarāshram's guidance, the Shrivali Trust was established which has provided high quality medical care and drinking water to the people. Free value-based education is provided at the Shrivali School . Temples have been reconstructed from the state of ruin and general infrastructure developed. The Shri Chitrapur Math Charitable Trust today works for the empowerment of the villagers providing livelihood to the underprivileged. Swamiji has stressed the development of the youth as a force and has resulted in the conducting of very many ''[[Chitrapur Math#Shibhirs|Shibhirs]]'' (youth camps) for the physical, mental and spiritual development of the youth in the community. ==Conclusion== The "Guru Parampara" of the Sāraswat Brahmins is something that they cherish and will always remain as the vital link that connects this small community of people, living in different parts of the globe, together.{{cite web|title = Guru Parampara| url =http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm| accessdate = 2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} ==References== * {{cite book|title = Anugraha - A Saga of cascading grace|last = Divgi|first = Jyothi|publisher = Shri Chitrapur Math Publication|url = http://www.chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071017152230/http://chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM|archivedate = 2007-10-17|df = }} * {{cite book|title=Guruparampara Charita Saramrita|publisher=Shri Chitrapur Math Publication|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017152230/http://chitrapurmath.net/books/BOOKS.HTM|archivedate=2007-10-17|df=}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm|title= Guru Parampara|accessdate=2007-06-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030418/http://www.chitrapurmath.net/parampara/guru_parampara.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} ==Notes== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} [[Category:Hindu denominations]]

The '''Chunara''' are an [[ethnic group]] found in the state of [[Gujarat]] in [[India]]. A small number are also found in the port city of [[Karachi]] in [[Pakistan]]. There are now two communities of Chunara, one [[Hindu]] and the other [[Muslim]].<ref name="people_of_india">People of India Gujarat Volume XXI Part One edited by R.B. Lal, P.B.S.V. Padmanabham, G. Krishnan and M. Azeez Mohideen pages 298-299</ref>
==Origin== The word chunara in [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] literally means someone who manufactures chuna (lime). According to their traditions, they were originally [[Rajput]]s who migrated from [[Rajasthan]] to [[Gujarat]] and joined the army of [[Gaekwar]]s of Baroda. After having a fall out with their employer, the [[Maratha]] ruler of [[Baroda]], they took to manufacturing lime. A section of the Chunara then converted to [[Islam]], and there are now distinct communities, one [[Hindu]] and the other [[Muslim]].<ref name="people_of_india"/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=d8yFaNRcYcsC&pg=PA298&dq=CHUNARA&hl=en&ei=VXv7TJnbJo2GrAfuyrHKCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=CHUNARA&f=false Chunara Community] Gujarat, Part 1 By Kumar Suresh Singh, Rajendra Behari Lal, Anthropological Survey of India.</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Jw9uAAAAMAAJ&q=CHUNARA&dq=CHUNARA&hl=en&ei=VXv7TJnbJo2GrAfuyrHKCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBQ Chunara] India's communities, Volume 1 by Kumar Suresh Singh, Anthropological Survey of India.</ref>The Kadias and Bricklayers are also called Chunaras or lime-men whose main profession is brick laying, though a few among them work as masons.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}(BY DEPARTMENT OF CENSUS, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA)
==Present circumstances== Some members communities still own lime kilns employing other Chunaras. Other than selling lime, some Chunara are now also petty businessmen. The Chunara are endogamous, with the [[Hindu]] section practising clan exogamy. The [[Muslim]] Chunara marry close kin, and practice both cross cousin and parallel cousin marriages. For the [[Hindu]] community, the goddess Hinglaj Mata is a tribal deity. The [[Muslim]]s belong to the [[Sunni]] sect.<ref name="people_of_india"/>
==See also== * [[Vanzha]]

{{about|the building|other uses|Church (disambiguation){{!}}Church}} {{Redirect|Church house|other uses|Church House (disambiguation){{!}}Church House}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} [[File:Evanjelický Kostol Štrba.jpg|thumb|[[Evangelical Lutheran]] church building in [[Štrba]], [[Slovakia]]. A typical village church in [[Europe]].]] [[File:Madeleine Paris.jpg|thumb|[[La Madeleine, Paris|La Madeleine]], a [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]], [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] church in [[Paris]], [[France]].]] [[File:Church of Saint Simeon Stylites 01.jpg|thumb|The [[Church of Saint Simeon Stylites]] in [[Aleppo]], [[Syria]], is considered to be one of the [[List of oldest church buildings|oldest surviving church buildings in the world]].]] A '''church building''' or '''church house''', often simply called a '''church''', is a building used for [[Christian]] religious activities, particularly for [[worship]] services. The term is often used by [[Christian]]s to refer to the physical buildings where they worship, but it is sometimes used (by analogy) to refer to buildings of other [[religion]]s.<ref>Use of the term [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/362167/Manichaeism "The Manichaean Church"], ''Encyclopædia Britannica''</ref> In traditional [[Christian architecture]], the church is often arranged in the shape of a [[Christian cross]]. When viewed from [[plan view]] the longest part of a cross is represented by the [[aisle]] and the junction of the cross is located at the [[altar]] area.
Towers or domes are often added with the intention of directing the eye of the viewer towards the [[heaven]]s and inspiring visitors. Modern church buildings have a variety of [[architectural style]]s and layouts; many buildings that were designed for other purposes have now been converted for church use, and conversely many original church buildings have been put to other uses.
The earliest identified Christian church building was a [[house church]] founded between 233 and 256. From the 11th through the 14th centuries, a wave of building of [[Cathedral architecture of Western Europe|cathedrals]] and smaller [[parish church]]es were erected across [[Western Europe]]. A [[cathedral]] is a church building, usually [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]], [[Protestant]] ([[Anglican]]), [[Eastern Orthodox]], or [[Oriental Orthodox]], housing a [[cathedra]], the formal name for the [[episcopal see|seat]] or [[throne]] of a presiding [[bishop]].
==Etymology== In [[Greek language|Greek]], the adjective ''kyriak-ós/-ē/-ón'' ({{lang|grc|[[wikt:κυριακόν|κυριακόν]]}}) means "belonging, or pertaining, to a ''[[Kyrios]]''" ("Lord"), and the usage was adopted by [[early Christians]] of the Eastern Mediterranean with regard to anything pertaining to the Lord [[Jesus Christ]]: hence "''Kyriakós oíkos''" ({{lang|grc|Kυριακός οίκος}}) ("house of the Lord", church), "''Kyriakē''" ({{lang|grc|Κυριακή}}) ("[the day] of the Lord", i.e. [[Sunday]]), or "''Kyriakē proseukhē''" ({{lang-el|Κυριακή προσευχή}}) (the "[[Lord's Prayer]]").<ref name="OEtymDChurch">{{Cite web |title=Church |url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=church |website=Online Etymology Dictionary |access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Anglo-Saxon Chronicle - cyrican.jpg|thumb|"Cyrican" was an Old English word for churches and church property]] In standard Greek usage, the older word "ecclesia" ({{lang-el|ἐκκλησία}}, ''ekklesía'', literally "assembly", "congregation", or the place where such a gathering occurs) was retained to signify both a specific edifice of Christian worship (a "[[wikt:church|'''c'''hurch"]]), and the overall community of the faithful ([[wikt:Church|the "'''C'''hurch"]]). This usage was also retained in [[Latin]] and the languages derived from Latin (e.g. French ''église'', Italian ''chiesa'', Spanish ''iglesia'', Portuguese ''igreja'', etc.), as well as in the [[Celtic languages]] (Welsh ''eglwys'', Irish ''eaglais'', Breton ''iliz'', etc.) and in Turkish (''kilise'').<ref name="OEtymDChurch" />
In the [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] and some [[Slavic languages]], the word ''kyriak-ós/-ē/-ón'' was adopted instead and derivatives formed thereof. In [[Old English]] the sequence of derivation started as "cirice", then [[Middle English]] "churche", and eventually "church" in its current pronunciation. German ''Kirche'', Scots ''kirk'', Russian {{lang|ru|церковь}} (''tserkov''), etc., are all similarly derived.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aggressivechristianity.net/articles/ecclesia.htm|title=THE CORRECT MEANING OF "CHURCH" AND "ECCLESIA"|website=www.aggressivechristianity.net|access-date=2016-06-22}}</ref>
==History==
===Antiquity=== According to the [[New Testament]], the earliest Christians did not build church buildings. Instead, they gathered in homes ([https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts%2017:5 Acts 17:5], [https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts+20%3A20&version=NIV 20:20], [https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1+corinthians+16%3A19&version=NIV 1 Corinthians 16:19]) or in Jewish worship places like the [[Second Temple]] or [[synagogue]]s ([https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=acts+2%3A46&version=NIV Acts 2:46], [https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=acts+19%3A8&version=NIV 19:8]). The earliest archeologically identified Christian church is a [[house church]] (''domus ecclesiae''), the [[Dura-Europos church]], founded between 233 and 256.<ref>{{cite book |last=Snyder |first=Graydon F. |title=Ante Pacem: Archaeological Evidence of Church Life Before Constantine |publisher=Mercer University Press |year=2003 |pp=128}}</ref> In the second half of the 3rd century AD, the first purpose-built halls for Christian worship (''aula ecclesiae'') began to be constructed. Although many of these were destroyed early in the next century during the [[Diocletianic Persecution]], even larger and more elaborate church buildings began to appear during the reign of the Emperor [[Constantine the Great]].<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Hartog |editor1-first=Paul |date= |title=The Contemporary Church and the Early Church: Case Studies in Ressourcement |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hlqUCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT70&dq=early+church+buildings&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwipkrWVip3VAhUMD8AKHdfuD5AQ6AEILTAC#v=onepage&q=early%20church%20buildings&f=false |location= |publisher=Pickwick Publications |page= |isbn= 978-1606088999 }} (Chapter 3)</ref>
===Medieval times=== [[File:Frauenkirche München abends.jpg|thumb|The [[Munich Frauenkirche|Frauenkirche]] in [[Munich]] is a largely [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]], medieval church.]] From the 11th through the 14th centuries, a wave of building of [[Cathedral architecture of Western Europe|cathedrals]] and smaller parish churches occurred across [[Western Europe]]. In addition to being a place of worship, the cathedral or the parish church was used by the community in other ways. It could serve as a meeting place for [[guilds]] or a hall for [[banquet]]s. [[Mystery plays]] were sometimes performed in cathedrals, and cathedrals might also be used for [[fair]]s. The church could be used as a place to thresh and store grain.<ref>{{cite book |last=Levy |title=Cathedrals and the Church |page=12}}</ref>
==== Romanesque architecture ==== Between 1000 and 1200 the [[Romanesque architecture|romanesque]] style became popular across [[Europe]]. While the name of the romanesque era refers to the tradition of [[Ancient Roman architecture|Roman architecture]], it was actually a West- and Central European trend. Romanesque buildings appear rather bulky and compact. Typical features are [[Arch|circular arches]], round or [[octagon]]al towers and [[Capital (architecture)|cushion capitals]] on the pillars. In the early romanesque era, [[coffer]]ing on the ceiling was fashionable, while later in the same era, [[Groin vault|groined vault]] was more popular. The rooms became wider and the motivs of [[sculpture]]s became more epic.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=g3HgsgEACAAJ&dq=romanesque+architecture&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjN5bDd2-PVAhVIrRQKHfNkBHUQ6AEIPjAD|title=Romanesque: Architecture, Sculpture, Painting|last=Toman|first=Rolf|date=2015-04-30|publisher=h.f.ullmann|isbn=9783848008407|language=en}}</ref>
==== Gothic architecture ==== The [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style emerged around 1140 in [[Île-de-France]] and spread through all of Europe. The gothic buildings were less compact than they had been in the romanesque era and often contained [[symbol]]ic and [[Allegory|allegoric]] features. For the first time, [[pointed arch]]es, [[rib vault]]s and [[buttress]]es were used, with the result that massive walls were not longer needed to stabilise the building. Due to that advantage, the area of the windows became bigger, which resulted in a brighter and more friendly atmosphere inside the church. The [[nave]] became higher and so did the pillars and the church steeple. The amibition to test out the limits of the architectural possibilities resulted in the collapse of several towers. In [[Germany]] and the [[Netherlands]], but also in [[Spain]], it became popular to build [[hall church]]es, in which every [[Vault (architecture)|vault]] has the same height.
Cathedrals were built in a very lavish way, as in the romanesque era. Examples for that are the [[Notre-Dame de Paris]] and the [[Reims Cathedral|Notre-Dame de Reims]] in France, but also the [[San Francesco d'Assisi, Palermo|San Francesco d’Assisi]] in [[Palermo]], the [[Salisbury Cathedral]] and the [[Wool church|Wool Church]] in [[Lavenham]], [[England]].
Many gothic churches contain features from the romanesque era. Some of the most well-known gothic churches stayed unfinished for hundreds of years, after the gothic style was not popular anymore. About half of the [[Cologne Cathedral]] was for example build in the 19th century.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=LBZ6781vvOwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=gothic+architecture&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiskNCu2-PVAhWF6RQKHXAFA_EQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Gothic Architecture|last=Frankl|first=Paul|last2=Crossley|first2=Paul|date=2000|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300087993|language=en}}</ref>
=== Renaissance === In the 15th and 16th century, the change in ethics and society due to the [[Renaissance]] and the [[Reformation]] also influenced the building of churches. The common style was much like the gothic style, but in a simplified way. The [[basilica]] was not the most popular type of church anymore, but instead [[hall church]]es were built. Typical features are columns and classical [[Capital (architecture)|capitals]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=70m1KbuD5YoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=renaissance+architecture&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWwu-Bo-TVAhUDORQKHfd9B3YQ6AEINTAC#v=onepage&q=renaissance%20architecture&f=false|title=Renaissance Architecture|last=Anderson|first=Christy|date=2013-02-28|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=9780192842275|language=en}}</ref>
In [[Protestantism|Protestant churches]], where the proclamation of God's Word is of special importance, the visitor's line of view is directed towards the [[pulpit]].
=== Baroque architecture === The [[Baroque architecture|baroque]] style was first used in [[Italy]] around 1575. From there it spread to the rest of Europe and to the European colonies. During the baroque era, the building industry increased heavily. Buildings, even churches, were used as indicators for wealth, authority and influence.The use of forms known from the [[renaissance]] were extremely exaggerated. [[Dome]]s and [[Capital (architecture)|capitals]] were decorated with moulding and the former [[Stucco|stucco-sculptures]] were replaced by [[fresco]] paintings on the ceilings. For the first time, churches were seen as one connected work of art and consistent artistic concepts were developed. Instead of long buildings, more central-plan buildings were created. The sprawling decoration with floral ornamentation and mythological motives raised until about 1720 to the [[Rococo|rococo era]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=eaC7yKbxj8UC&printsec=frontcover&dq=baroque+architecture&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi14YH0rOTVAhXQERQKHZaZDEoQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=baroque%20architecture&f=false|title=Pietro Da Cortona and Roman Baroque Architecture|last=Merz|first=Jörg Martin|date=2008|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300111231|language=en}}</ref>
The [[Protestantism|Protestant parishes]] preferred lateral churches, in which all the visitors could be as close as possible to the [[pulpit]] and the [[altar]].
==Architecture== {{main article|Church architecture}} [[File:Norwich Cathedral from Cloisters, Norfolk, UK - Diliff.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Norwich Cathedral]] in England is an example of a Cathedral complex built during the [[Middle Ages]].]] A common architecture for churches is the shape of a [[Christian cross|cross]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=dqIZAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover|title=Remarks on Church Architecture ...|last=Petit|first=John Louis|date=1841|publisher=J. Burns|language=en}}</ref> (a long central rectangle, with side rectangles, and a rectangle in front for the [[altar]] space or sanctuary). These churches also often have a [[dome]] or other large [[vault (architecture)|vaulted]] space in the interior to represent or draw attention to the heavens. Other common shapes for churches include a circle, to represent eternity, or an [[octagon]] or similar star shape, to represent the church's bringing light to the world. Another common feature is the [[spire]], a tall tower on the "west" end of the church or over the [[crossing (architecture)|crossing]].
Another common feature of many Christian churches is the [[Orientation of churches|eastwards orientation]] of the front [[altar]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sacredarchitecture.org/articles/sacred_places_the_significance_of_the_church_building/|title=The Institute for Sacred Architecture {{!}} Articles {{!}} Sacred Places: The Significance of the Church Building|website=www.sacredarchitecture.org|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref> Often, the altar will not be oriented due east, but in the direction of sunrise. This tradition originated in Byzantium in the 4th century, and becomes prevalent in the West in the 8th to 9th century. The old Roman custom of having the altar at the west end and the entrance at the east was sometimes followed as late as the 11th century even in areas of northern Europe under Frankish rule, as seen in [[Petershausen (Constance)]], [[Bamberg Cathedral]], [[Augsburg Cathedral]], [[Regensburg Cathedral]], and [[Hildesheim Cathedral]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=sX8w667tblMC&pg=PA12&dq=%22XI+Jahrh+fortgedauert%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwir9NbtjObLAhWHDg8KHUFVA8kQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=%22XI%20Jahrh%20fortgedauert%22&f=false Heinrich Otte, ''Handbuch der kirchlichen Kunst-Archäologie des deutschen Mittelalters'' (Leipzig 1868), p. 12]</ref>
==Types== ===Basilica=== {{main article|Basilica}} The [[Latin]] word basilica (derived from [[Greek language|Greek]], ''[[Stoa Basileios|Basiliké Stoà]]'', Royal ''[[Stoa]]'') was originally used to describe a [[ancient Rome|Roman]] public building (as in [[Greece]], mainly a [[tribunal]]), usually located in the [[Forum (Roman)|forum]] of a Roman town.<ref name="OXFORD1">[https://books.google.com/books?id=Te2dAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA117 ''The Oxford Dictionary of Christian Art and Architecture''] (2013 {{ISBN|978-0-19968027-6}}), p. 117</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacredarchitecture.org/articles/the_eschatological_dimension_of_church_architecture|title=The Institute for Sacred Architecture - Articles- The Eschatological Dimension of Church Architecture|publisher=}}</ref>
After the [[Roman Empire]] became [[Edict of Thessalonica|officially Christian]], the term came by extension to refer to a large and important church that has been given special ceremonial rights by the [[Pope]]. Thus the word retains two senses today, one architectural and the other ecclesiastical.[[File:St. Peter and St. Paul's Church 1, Vilnius, Lithuania - Diliff.jpg|thumb|left|Central [[nave]] of [[St. Peter and St. Paul's Church, Vilnius]], Lithuania looking north-east towards the altar. An example of a [[Baroque]] church interior.]]
===Cathedral=== {{main article|Architecture of cathedrals and great churches}} {{see|Duomo}} [[File:Sant Vasily cathedral in Moscow.JPG|thumb|upright=0.8|[[Saint Basil's Cathedral]] in [[Moscow]], Russia (today a museum) is a famous and characteristic example of a [[Russian Orthodox Church]] building.]] A [[cathedral]] is a church, usually [[Catholic Church|Catholic]], [[Anglican]], [[Oriental Orthodox]] or [[Eastern Orthodox]], housing the seat of a bishop. The word cathedral takes its name from ''[[cathedra]]'', or Bishop's Throne (In {{lang-la|ecclesia cathedralis}}). The term is sometimes (improperly) used to refer to any church of great size.
A church that has the function of cathedral is not necessarily a large building. It might be as small as [[Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford|Christ Church Cathedral]] in [[Oxford]], England, [[Sacred Heart Cathedral (Raleigh, North Carolina)|Sacred Heart Cathedral]] in [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh, United States]], or [[Chur]] Cathedral in [[Switzerland]]. However, frequently, the cathedral along with some of the abbey churches, was the [[List of largest buildings in the world|largest building]] in any region.
===Pilgrimage church=== {{main|Pilgrimage church}} A pilgrimage church is a church to which [[pilgrimage]]s are regularly made, or a church along a pilgrimage route, often located at the tomb of a [[saint]]s, or holding icons or [[relic]]s to which miraculous properties are ascribed, the site of [[Marian apparition]]s, etc.
===Conventual church=== {{see|Priory|Katholikon}} {{commonscat|Monastery church}} A conventual church (or monastery church, [[Minster (church)|minster]], ''[[katholikon]]'') is the main church building in a Christian [[monastery]] or [[abbey]].
===Collegiate church=== {{main|Collegiate church}} A collegiate church is a church where the [[daily office]] of worship is maintained by a [[college (canon law)|college]] of [[canon (priest)|canons]], which may be presided over by a [[Dean (religion)|dean]] or [[Provost (religion)|provost]]. Collegiate churches were often supported by extensive lands held by the church, or by [[tithe]] income from [[impropriation|appropriated]] [[benefices]]. They commonly provide distinct spaces for congregational worship and for the choir offices of their clerical community.
===Alternative buildings=== {{see|Road church|Simultaneum}} Old and disused church buildings can be seen as an interesting proposition for developers as the architecture and location often provide for attractive homes<ref>{{cite news| url=http://property.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/property/new_homes/article3047285.ece |work=The Times |location=London | title=Church conversions | first=Lucy | last=Alexander | date=14 December 2007 | accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref> or city centre entertainment venues<ref>{{cite web|author=Site design and technology by Lightmaker.com |url=http://www.pitcherandpiano.com/locations/bar.cfm?area=Nottingham |title=quality food and drink |publisher=Pitcher and Piano |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> On the other hand, many newer churches have decided to host meetings in public buildings such as schools,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.familychurchchristchurch.org.uk |title=Welcome to the Family Church Christchurch Dorset |publisher=The Family Church Christchurch |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> universities,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-hope.org.uk |title=Welcome to The Hope Church, Manchester... A Newfrontiers Church based in Salford, Greater Manchester UK |publisher=The-hope.org.uk |accessdate=18 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202171948/http://www.the-hope.org.uk/ |archivedate=2 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> cinemas<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jubileechurchlondon.org|title=Jubilee Church London|work=jubileechurchlondon.org}}</ref> or theatres.<ref>{{cite web |title=Welcome to Hillsong Church |url=http://hillsong.com/uk/ |website=Hillsong Church UK |access-date=25 November 2016}}</ref>
There is another trend to convert old buildings for [[worship]] rather than face the construction costs and planning difficulties of a new build. Unusual venues in the UK include an old Tram power station,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.city-church.co.uk |title=CITY CHURCH NEWCASTLE & GATESHEAD – enjoying God...making friends...changing lives – Welcome |publisher=City-church.co.uk |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> a former [[bus garage]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aylshamcommunitychurch.org |title=Aylsham Community Church |publisher=Aylsham Community Church |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> an old cinema and [[Bingo (UK)|bingo]] hall,<ref>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Reg|year=2004|title=Things are different now: A short history of Winchester Family Church|publisher=Winchester Family Church|location=Winchester|page=11}}</ref> a former [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]] Drill Hall,<ref>{{cite web|title=ABOUT|url=http://www.barnabascommunitychurch.com/about.html|website=www.barnabascommunitychurch.com|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> and a former synagogue.<ref>{{cite web|title=Where We Meet|url=http://www.citychurchsheffield.org.uk/where-we-meet|website=City Church Sheffield|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> A windmill has also been converted into a church at [[Reigate Heath Windmill|Reigate Heath]].
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:BaptistchurchJHB31-07-2016.jpeg|thumb|right| A [[Baptist Church]] in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]].]] --> There has been an increase in partnerships between church management and private real estate companies to redevelop church properties into mixed uses. While it has garnered criticism from some, the partnership offers congregations the opportunity to increase revenue while preserving the property.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Churches Redeveloping Properties to Give Them New Life|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/churches-redeveloping-properties-to-give-them-new-life-1443519001|newspaper = Wall Street Journal|access-date = 2015-10-23|issn = 0099-9660|first = Robyn A.|last = Friedman}}</ref>
